content:
• Friday, August 30, 2013

  • After-hours Gainers / Losers

    • After-hours top gainers, as of 5:15 p.m.: TEN +5%. AMAP +3%. PLAB +2%. EOPN +2%. TRX +2%.
    • After-hours top losers: HXM -9%. OPK -4%. VET -2%. IBN -2%. HW -1%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:34 PM | 1 Comment

  • The week's ETF movers - Gainers / Losers

    • The week's ETF movers - Gainers: VXX +15.20%. EWY +2.89%. BNO +2.80%. UNG +2.43%. TLT +1.63%.
    • ETF Losers: GDX -6.67%. GDXJ -6.05%. TAN -4.33%. EPI -4.14%. EWJ -3.98%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:40 PM
  • NVIV

    InVivo closes out dismal week with big loss

    • Make no mistake, it was not a good week for shares of InVivo Therapeutics (NASDAQ:NVIV) which fell 18% on the day.
    • The shares are off some 66% from Monday's intraday high.
    • "The FDA’s increasing caution over biological grafts has been evident for a while, but seems to have caught NVIV investors by surprise," SA contributor EP Vantage said, in an article published Thursday afternoon.
    • Previously: NVIV plunges on update to clinical plan
     
     
     
     
    | 4:04 PM
  • ALTI

    Altair Nanotechnologies appoints a new CEO

    Altair Nanotechnologies (NASDAQ:ALTI) -3% says it's appointed Richard W. Lee as chief executive officer. Mr. R Lee, age 73, most recently served as managing director of DCM Management Consulting Ltd., a Hong Kong-based consulting firm. He succeeds Alex Lee, who resigned from his position as CEO of the company on August 26.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:00 PM
  • APA

    Sinopec-Apache deal shows China's demand for resources remains strong

    • Apache (APA +9.2%) may have "knocked it out of the park" with its sale of a third of its Egypt oil and gas assets to Sinopec (SNP -1.2%) for $3.1B (I, II), but the reaction toward SNP is more ambiguous.
    • The deal, China's biggest investment in the Middle East to date, shows a continued global search for energy and resources to feed an economy growing at a 7%-plus annual rate and a higher tolerance for risk than its western counterparts; note that PetroChina (NYSE:PTR) reportedly is in talks to acquire 25% of Exxon's (NYSE:XOM) West Qurna-1 oilfield in Iraq.
    • The deal also could provide a boost for other energy producers with significant operations in the region; Occidental Petroleum (OXY -0.2%) produces ~37% of its total output in the Middle East and North Africa, and is thought to be looking to sell all or part of those assets.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:48 PM
  • SN

    Sanchez Energy +5% after RBC upgrades shares

    • Sanchez Energy (SN +5.2%) is upgraded to Outperform from Sector Perform with a $27 price target, up from $23, at RBC Capital.
    • The firm lifted its rating based on strength in Palmetto and TMS exposure after closing on a 40K acre acquisition.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:12 PM
  • ECTE

    Echo Therapeutics largest shareholder launches a salvo at the company's board

    • Echo Therapeutics' (OTC:ECTE +10%) largest shareholder, Platinum-Montaur Life Sciences, has sent a letter to the company's board of directors urging it to "stop the destruction of shareholder value."
    • The letter details a multi-point plan that Platinum-Montaur believes would return the market value of the company's stock after years of precipitous decline.
    • Among the proposals include provisions for the removal and replacement of certain directors, engaging a consulting firm to help establish and implement a strategic vision, and that the company retain a recruiting firm to hire a permanent CEO with "bona fide medical device development credentials."
    • Platinum-Montaur owns around 20% of the company's float.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:59 PM | 1 Comment
  • GCO

    Genesco weaker for second day following Q2 results

    • There's no respite for Genesco (GCO -3.5%) as the shares fall again after suffering through a miserable session Thursday — the two day decline now sits at ~12%.
    • The retailer missed on both lines with its Q2 report Thursday, but it was likely the guidance that tanked the stock.
    • Management lowered its EPS guidance for FY14 to $5.20-5.30 from $5.57-5.67 against consensus of $5.39. (PR)
    • CEO Robert Dennis is "confident [GCO is] doing the right things to ensure it once again emerges [from the uncertain consumer environment] with its dominant market positions intact."
     
     
     
     
    | 2:53 PM
  • MKTO

    Marketo -4.8% on plan to offer 6M shares

    • Marketo (MKTO -4.8%) slumps nearly 5% after the software maker said plans a public offering of 6M shares of common stock.
    • The offering is expected to consist of 5.3M shares from existing shareholders and ~700K shares offered by the company; MTKO has ~37M shares outstanding.
    • Proceeds from the MKTO portion of the offering will be used to fund general corporate purposes.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:52 PM
  • TROV

    TrovaGene slides, article explores company's potential

    • Shares of TrovaGene (TROV -12.7%) have moved steadily lower throughout the session and are now down double-digits on twice their average 10-day volume.
    • Perhaps weighing on sentiment is an ostensibly bullish article from SA contributor Douglas House which, upon a closer read, has some rather disconcerting things to say about the company's prospects.
    • House flags "nosebleed" numbers for price/ book, revenue/ share, price/ to sales, and revenue/ employee and characterizes the status of TrNA testing as "embryonic."
    • After a lengthy review, the author does note several "TROV-specific events [that should] bolster the company's prospects over the next 1-2 years," but it's probably the last paragraph that comes across the most bearish: "This stock is not for buy-and-hold types because of its speculative nature [and] if you hold onto your position expecting to see ... the company blossoming into the next Celgene, it ain't going to happen."
     
     
     
     
    | 2:32 PM
  • YGE

    Ardour Capital ups Yingli Green Energy to Buy on the back of its Q2 earnings report

    • Yingli Green Energy (YGE +1.8%) bucks a weak tape on a solid Q2. Ardour Capital likes what its sees too, upgrading the shares from Hold to Buy on the back of the report.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:32 PM
  • PG

    Minor flash crash disrupts trading in Procter & Gamble

    • Shares of Procter & Gamble (PG +0.3%) took a sharp turn south in a mini-flash crash before recovering.
    • The abrupt movement is unexplained at the moment, although the 5% drop in milliseconds on no news has traders guessing a fat-fingered entry is to blame.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:16 PM | 3 Comments
  • MGCD

    MGC Diagnostics gains on a solid FQ3 EPS beat

    • MGC Diagnostics (MGCD +13.7%) puts up a big gain today despite a weak overall market, after its FQ3 EPS easily topped estimates, turning to profit from a loss in the prior year period.
    • Total evenue grew by 15% over Q312.
    • Service revenue +29% on a year-over-year basis, while service gross margin improved to 70.8%, compared to 65.3% in Q312.
    • Overall gross margin improved 170 basis points to 55.4%, compared to 53.7% in last year's third quarter.
    • Attachment Rate of point-of-sale extended service contracts grew to 26%, compared to 3% in the prior year period.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:12 PM
  • NUAN

    Nuance Communications up on increased Icahn stake

    • Shares of Nuance Communications (NUAN +2.6%) are trading up after Carl Icahn disclosed an increased 16.9% stake in the company.
    • FBR's Daniel Ives sees a number of potential scenarios playing out: Icahn could move to agitate for board representation, remove CEO Paul Ricci, carve the businesses up, and/or sell Nuance further down the road. The most probable first step is a push for board representation, Ives says. The WSJ speculates the same.
    • For now, Ives believes Icahn's increased involvement will serve to put a floor on NUAN's price - welcome news for investors who have seen shares fall 20.6% in the last year.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:54 PM
  • QIHU

    J.P. Morgan likes Qihoo, Tencent among China mobile internet

    • The China mobile internet sector has collected enough users, J.P. Morgan says, and prefers Qihoo (QIHU -0.7%) and Tencent (OTCPK:TCEHY, OTCPK:TCTZF) because they have already amassed large mobile platforms.
    • Both companies should continue to capitalize on China’s booming mobile economy, the firm says; it expects Tencent to capture 30%-35% mobile game share by the end of 2014 through content development and distribution, while QIHU could take 10% through distribution.
    • The firm cuts Youku (YOKU -2.7%) and Sohu (SOHU -2.1%) to Neutral from Overweight.
    • JPM also likes online real estate services platform Soufun (SFUN +4.6%) for its market leading position; users seem sticky and barrier to entry seems high.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:48 PM
  • CTC

    Midday top 10 gainers /Losers

    • Midday top 10 gainers: CTC +18%. MGCD +14%. CRM +14%. SPLK +12%. KID +11%. CEP +11%. SOL +10%. TI +9%. MCOX +9%.
    • Midday top 10 Losers: AFFM.OB -18%. CMGE -16%. SHOS -16%. OVTI -16%. CTRL -15%. KKD -15%. TROV -12%. PSUN -12%. DANG -11%. OTC:IGC -10%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:45 PM | 3 Comments
  • GST

    Gastar announces extension on closing of Texas property sale

    • Gastar Exploration (GST -1.1%) agrees to provide Cubic Energy (CBNR.OB +6.6%) an additional extension until Sept. 20 on the closing of the previously announced sale of GST's east Texas properties.
    • As compensation for the extension, CBNR will pay GST an additional $1M at closing, bringing the total transaction value to $47M.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:59 AM
  • ASTX

    Feuerstein takes aim at Astex SGI-110 results, shares slide

    • Astex Pharmaceuticals (ASTX -4.1%) is notably weak today after running up ~25% on Wednesday following topline data from a Phase 2 trial of SGI-110.
    • Not helping the stock's cause is an article from theStreet's Adam Feuerstein who takes issue with RBC analyst Michael Yee's bullish thesis.
    • "Concluding that SGI-110 is better than Dacogen [another ASTX product which is licensed to Eisai (OTCPK:ESALF)] based on an interim look at just 17 patients is silly," Feuerstein says, adding that the observed 53% response rate in the cohort of elderly patients with treatment-naive AML "will not hold up once the cohort ... reaches full enrollment."
    • Ultimately, Feuerstein thinks it's "premature to say much of anything about SGI-110's activity in AML relative to Dacogen based on the paltry and incomplete data released ... on Wednesday."
    • For the record, the company says it released interim results because "the data was material and ASH just cleared [the company] for top-line data release without violating the embargo."
     
     
     
     
    | 11:39 AM | 1 Comment
  • CRM

    Salesforce hits 52-week highs, analyst praise pours in

    • Salesforce.com (CRM +14%) shares gap up to 52-week highs a day after blowing past Wall Street estimates, and analyst praise continues to pour in.
    • CRM “remains by a wide margin the fastest growing company of its size [which] should be able to keep its impressive growth trajectory relatively intact for at least the next 6-8 quarters," Canaccord says in reiterating its Buy rating.
    • Credit Suisse raises its price target to $60 from $52.50 as the company "most leveraged to the massive technology refresh and expansion cycle across the B2B and B2C CRM segments."
    • Earlier analyst commentary: I, II.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:32 AM | 1 Comment
  • BEBE

    Lackluster outlook, negative comps sink bebe shares

    • Shares of bebe stores (OTC:BEBE -6%) tumble on the heels of a FQ4 report which showed comps growth (as expected) was -7.1% for the period.
    • Net sales dropped 9.4% Y/Y and gross margin fell 960 bps.
    • SG&A jumped  $10.3M to 48.5% of sales from 36.1% of sales in Q4 2012, although the increase was stripped out of the adjusted EPS figure.
    • Q1 2014 outlook: Comps growth "in the negative low to mid-single digit range." Lower gross margin due to higher markdowns. Front-loaded SG&A is expected to "negatively impact" Q1 results. Net loss per share "in the range of low to mid-teens per share." BEBE plans to open one new bebe store and one 2B store in 2014 and expects to close as many as 10 bebe stores and five 2b stores during the year. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:17 AM
  • JBT

    John Bean Technologies lands a 5-year contract from Jetway

    • John Bean Technologies (JBT -1.1%) says its JBT AeroTech unit has won a five-year contract worth more than $17M to deliver Jetway aviation support equipment to a global airframe manufacturer.
    • The order is for approximately 40 mobile bleed air carts and support equipment and for on-the-ground compressed air for aircraft environmental control system testing, to be delivered through 2018.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:06 AM
  • APA

    Apache surprises analysts with impressive price in Egypt asset sale

    • Apache's (APA +7.6%) ability to close the $3.1B sale to Sinopec (SNP -1.5%) for its Egypt assets at a surprisingly high price is impressive in light of the political turmoil in the region, Simmons analysts say.
    • The deal implied a total Egypt asset value of $9.3B, higher than estimates of ~$7.7B, and it also came early, with expectations centering around a move in 2014, the firm says.
    • Egypt likely accounts for 20% of APA's current production, 25% of its cash flow, "and a disproportionately larger share of investor concerns."
     
     
     
     
    | 10:46 AM
  • KTOS

    Kratos slumps; KeyBanc hikes PT

    • Kratos Defense & Security (KTOS -5.3%) shares are slumping on no apparent news but remain up 19.9% on the month.
    • Earlier, KeyBanc hiked its PT to $10 from $8 and maintained its Buy rating, citing the company's improved FCF generation ability following a debt refinancing as well as its lure as an acquisition target.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:45 AM
  • PWRD

    Chinese game makers fall in sympathy after yesterday's Shanda wallop

    • Today's downturn in Chinese game makers is outpacing a broader tick down in the Chinese tech space (CQQQ -0.2%). Perfect World (PWRD -1.5%), NetEase (NTES -4.7%), and Giant Interactive (GA -2.4%) are falling in sympathy after Shanda Games (GAME) was walloped yesterday following a Q2 beat.
    • NetEase is the lame duck, as a downgrade from JPMorgan to Neutral (albeit with a PT hike to $75 from $65) weighs the stock.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:29 AM
  • CMLS

    Cumulus Media acquires Dial Global, makes other strategic moves

    • Cumulus Media (CMLS +4%) will acquire Dial Global (OTCPK:DIAL-OLD +83.3%) for $260M in cash ($45M equity/ $215M to retire the company's debt).
    • CMLS will also sell 53 radio stations to Townsquare Media for $238M in cash. In addition, CMLS will trade Townsquare 15 stations "in two small and mid-sized markets" for five stations in Fresno.
    • The deal for Dial Global gives CMLS new "NFL, NCAA, NASCAR, Olympics, AP Radio News and NBC News" content as well as "other popular programming."
    • "These transactions give us the necessary scale to provide the marketing and enterprise solutions our advertising and affiliate partners require," CEO Lew Dickey says. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 10:19 AM
  • SNBR

    KeyBanc upgrades Select Comfort, shares rise

    • "We ... met with management ... and consistent with its Q2 commentary, we came away more confident that the company has rectified marketing issues that were detrimental to H1 results," KeyBanc's Bradley Thomas says, upgrading shares of Select Comfort (SCSS +3.5%) to Buy from Hold.
    • KeyBanc's channel checks on the Dual Temp topper reportedly show ramping product sales. "Our August checks suggest a run-rate that could add 6-8% to sales (on an annualized rate)," Thomas notes.
    • Management talked quite a bit about marketing and the DualTemp on last quarter's CC. (transcript)
    • Price target is $30, representing a 25% upside from Thursday's close.
    • See also: Longbow upgrades SCSS
     
     
     
     
    | 10:01 AM
  • PSUN

    Janney reiterates Buy on PacSun as shares slip

    • Janney is out with a note on Pacific Sunwear (PSUN -5.6%) following the retailer's Q2 results.
    • Analyst Adrienne Tennant says comps growth of 3% looks pretty good versus expectations and considering the environment — we said as much here Thursday.
    • Like Wedbush's Betty Chen, Tennant believes the company's "California-lifestyle" point of view is a good product strategy.
    • The quarterly results "highlight the success of dramatic changes that have taken place in the women’s business including building a new team, aging up the customer and transforming the merchandising from a tween or young teen to attract a much more fashion-savvy 17 to 24 year old," Tennant adds.
    • Buy rating reiterated, price target is $6.
    • More: Earnings, Q2 highlights, CC transcript
     
     
     
     
    | 9:35 AM
  • OVTI

    OmniVision continues fall PM amid 3 downgrades

    • Shares of OmniVision (NASDAQ:OVTI) are down 13.2% PM on mixed FQ1 results and soft guidance.
    • Northland downgraded OmniVision 1 notch to Perform and pulled its PT to $20 from $27.50.
    • Craig-Hallum lowered its rating to Hold from Buy and reduced its PT to $18 from $24.
    • Oppenheimer pulled its Buy rating earlier this morning.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:15 AM

  • Premarket Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: SOL +15%. SPLK +9%. CRM +9%. APA +8%. RDN +7%. RSOL +5%.
    • Losers: OVTI -13%. KKD -11%.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:11 AM
  • APA

    Apache's Egypt asset sale a "game-changer," Deutsche Bank says

    • Apache's (NYSE:APA) sale of a 33% stake in its Egypt business to Sinopec (NYSE:SNP) for $3.1B is a "game-changer," Deutsche Bank says, as it increases the momentum of change at APA and obtains value for an asset the market was discounting.
    • The deal rebalances the APA portfolio, with Egypt now comprising 15% of production vs. 20% in FY 2012.
    • The firm "embraces" the restructuring at APA and believes "there is more to come."
    • The lifting and de-risking of $3.1B of additional value from Egypt could see shares up $7-$8, DB says; APA +7.6% premarket.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:11 AM | 6 Comments
  • CRM

    Goldman reiterates CL-Buy on Salesforce

    • Another notable vote of confidence for Salesforce (NYSE:CRM) post-Q2 comes from Goldman, where analyst Heather Bellini reiterates a Conviction List Buy.
    • "We are forecasting reported bookings growth to continue to remain strong at 32% and 31% in FQ3 and FQ4," Bellini says, adding that "field work continues to underscore CRM’s growing strategic footprint within enterprise customers."
    • Price target: $60.
    • Earlier: The Street weighs in on CRM
     
     
     
     
    | 8:36 AM

  • Thailand deficit widens, Indonesia caps three-day rally

    • Thai shares (THD, TTF) close mostly flat after data showed the country's current account deficit widened to $709M last month from $664M in June. Stripping out gold imports the country would have shown a surplus of $255M. Thai Capital Fund: TF
    • Indonesian shares gained for a third session (previous), rising 2.2% in Jakarta and cutting losses to 9% for the month (still the worst month since 2008). EIDO +1.7% IDX +3% premarket. Indonesia SmallCap ETF: IDXJ
    • Philippine stocks finished 2.2% higher after rallying Thursday on better than expected GDP data.
    • Elsewhere in the region: Straits Times EWS, EWSS) -0.3%, KLCI (EWM) +1.4%, VNIndex (VNM) +0.9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:27 AM
  • KKD

    Krispy Kreme Doughnuts in focus

    • Krispy Kreme (KKD) execs didn't seem panicked about missing estimates slightly in Q2 as they pointed to the impact of refranchising, a smaller store format, and a strong comp from last year during the firm's conference call.
    • Looking ahead, the early report on comparable store sales for Q3 is "choppy" at best. The first three weeks of August average a 5.7% Y/Y gain in comp sales, ranging from a week of a 12% gain to a flat week.
    • Earnings call transcript
    • KKD -13.5% premarket.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:26 AM
  • CRM

    The Street shows love for Salesforce, shares up after Q2 results

    • Salesforce (NYSE:CRM) is a top pick at Deutsche as the bank says the shares are set to outperform the market after underperforming YTD. Price target raised to $58.
    • Macquarie also likes the quarter, noting that CRM 's "most important metric, normalized billings, grew +27% Y/Y (organic CC)." Macquarie had forecast 24% growth. FY14 non-GAAP EPS and revenue estimates raised to $0.34 (from $0.32) and $4.019B (from $4B) respectively. Outperform reiterated, price target raised to $50.
    • William Blair highlights a 16th straight decline in customer churn which "shows that the company continues to sign more enterprise customers and is becoming more critical to clients."
    • Wunderlich sees a "breakout upside."
    • Shares +9% premarket.
    • More: Earnings, Q2 highlights, CC transcript
     
     
     
     
    | 8:03 AM | 1 Comment
  • YGE

    Yingli Green Energy gains after earnings

    • Total PV module shipments up 23.6% from Q1. Gross margin of 11.8% vs. 4.1% in Q1. Operating margin of -3.8% vs. -12.1%.
    • Company notes strong demand from China and the U.S. is associated with typical peak seasons and accelerated construction of utility scale projects, but Europe "tracked better than expected."
    • Company reiterates module shipments guidance of 3.2-3.3GW for full year 2013.
    • CC at 8 ET.
    • YGE +3.6% premarket.
    • Also, reporting this morning, ReneSola soars.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:50 AM
  • SOL

    ReneSola soars after Q2 results

    • Gross margin of 7.3% exceeded company and guidance and compared to -2.0% in Q1.
    • Solar wafer and module shipments of 849.3 megawatts up 28.3% Q/Q, up 70.8% Y/Y. Company notes particularly strong demand from the U.S. and Japan.
    • Q3 outlook for shipments of 730-750MW, and gross margin of 7-9%.
    • CC at 8 ET.
    • SOL +10% premarket.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:39 AM | 1 Comment
  • OVTI

    OmniVision downgraded at Oppenheimer following earnings

    • Oppenheimer removes its Buy rating on OmniVision Technologies (NASDAQ:OVTI) after last night's earnings and soft guidance. "We've changed our mind on gross margin expansion."
    • Notable Calls takes note of a good call at OTR Global which earlier this week was cautious on the company ahead of the earnings report.
    • FQ1 results last night.
    • Shares off 12.4% premarket.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:25 AM
  • RDN

    Radian cuts legacy exposure in deal with Freddie Mac

    • Radian (NYSE:RDN) strikes a deal with Freddie Mac over 25,760 loans delinquent as of Dec. 31, 2011. The agreement caps Radian's exposure to this group at $840M. The mortgage insurer had already paid $370M and paid about $255M to Freddie upon the agreement - another $205M has been deposited into a collateral account to cover any further losses.
    • Radian will record a $20M charge to Q3 earnings in connection with the deal.
    • "One of our top priorities for our mortgage insurance business is to actively reduce our legacy exposure," says Radian CEO S.A. Ibrahim, noting the agreement reduces total primary loans by 12.6%.
    • Shares gained 1.8% in AH trading yesterday.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:02 AM

  • Global stocks mixed

    • Asian stocks trade mixed as markets stay cautious on the last trading day of month and ahead of the long Labor Day weekend in the U.S.
    • Similar factors are helping to push European shares lower, with the Syrian situation adding to the bearish sentiment.
    • "Traders remain reluctant to take on significantly new positions ahead of the long weekend in the U.S., especially when there remains so much uncertainty in the air," says market analyst Michael Hewson.
    • Japan -0.5%, Hong Kong +0.1%, China +0.1%, India +0.3%.
    • EU Stoxx 50 -0.5%, London -0.5%, Paris -0.5%, Frankfurt -0.6%, Milan -0.3%, Madrid -0.4%.
    • U.S. stock futures: Dow +0.05%, S&P +0.1%, Nasdaq +0.1%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:26 AM
  • AMX

    America Movil could drop KPN offer after foundation move

    • America Movil (AMX, AMOV) is prepared to withdraw its €7.2B takeover offer for KPN (OTCPK:KKPNF) after an independent foundation created to protect the interests of shareholders and other stakeholders moved to block the deal.
    • The foundation exercised an option to acquire almost 50% of KPN's voting stock, saying that those stakeholder interests were at risk because America Movil didn't consult with the Dutch telecom carrier before announcing its bid. However, the foundation is open to America Movil addressing its concerns.
    • KPN shares are -5.2% in Amsterdam.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:45 AM | 1 Comment
